snippet: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously that the Secret Service did not violate the free speech rights of a man who was arrested after confronting Vice President Dick Cheney in 2006.
abstract: Supreme Court unanimously rules against Steven Howards, a protester who said that his free speech rights had been violated in 2006 when Secret Service agents protecting Vice Pres Dick Cheney arrested him after he made critical remarks about the Bush administration’s war policies; court decides that Secret Service agents could not be sued.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously that the Secret Service did not violate the free speech rights of a man who was arrested after confronting Vice President Dick Cheney in 2006.

headline.seo: Secret Service Agents Can’t Be Sued, Justices Rule
headline.main: Protester Spurned in Bid To Sue the Secret Service
headline.print_headline: Protester Spurned in Bid To Sue the Secret Service
